{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3633590,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-22T19:40:51.941Z","cooked":"

While I am the lead mentor, my strengths are NOT as a programming lead. Yes, I can code, but I have poor habits and do not want to pass them along. So, with that confession, I am asking for guidance.

Our lead programming student tells me we need to set up 2FA to use VSCode with our Github. Assuming I stated and understand the issue correctly , what I would like to ask is: How are teams handling this? How is the code passed to the correct user to allow authentication?

billbo911:

tudent tells me we need to set up 2FA to use VSCode with our Github. Assuming I stated and understand the issue correctly , what I would like to ask is: How are teams handling this? How is the code passed to the correct

I assume you have a single team GutHub account login like 8513 does. We give a few students 2FA access to our account by using the google auth app. Instead of SMS 2FA we use the the “scan a QR code into an app” 2FA. There is no limit to the number of devices you can scan the QR code on so we can add whoever we want. Google authenticator can even share that login to another device after the initial setup.

EDIT: The correct thing to do is follow the advice below and make an organization.

We have a github organization that owns our repositories and everyone uses their own github accounts so there is no need for this. I would highly suggest looking into that instead of sharing a “team” account.

GitHub

FRC-4476-WAFFLES

Community FRC Team. FRC-4476-WAFFLES has 19 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.

@billbo911 I would strongly recommend making an organization instead of sharing an individual account for a few reasons:

  • Accountability - it’s easy to see who made what change, especially if there was a destructive action
  • Security - no need to ask “whose SSH key is that?” when a person’s access is tied to their personal account, not just a token
  • Permissions - You can give newer students access to open pull requests that a lead student can review and merge
  • It doesn’t cost anything, and is simpler for everyone involved

You can convert a user account to an organization by following the steps here: Converting a user into an organization - GitHub Docs
